title: Food superstitions
intro: Have you ever blown out the candles on a birthday cake and made a wish? Or thrown rice over the bride and groom at a wedding? Rob and Sam talk about food superstitions and teach you vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: The tradition of carving pumpkins, or Jack o’ Lanterns as they’re called in the United States, started out as a Celtic festival in Ireland - but it was the Americans who started using pumpkins. So what vegetable did the Irish originally use to scare away ghosts?
a) turnips b) potatoes c) squash
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: old, unscientific beliefs which are connected with magic rather than human reason
prevent someone or something from harming you; repel
bad luck or magical spells which have the power to cause bad things to happen
idiomatic phrase used to describe many examples of related things
foodstuff mixing fruit, spices, sugar and vinegar
show you what you should or should not do in the future, as a result of experience

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam, andI’m having a boiled egg for lunch today… I’ll just sprinkle some salt on top – there!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, you’ve spilled some salt on the floor, Sam! Quick, throw some over your left shoulder.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Throw salt over my shoulder?! What are you talking about, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It’s bad luck to spill salt!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Oh dear! It looks like Rob believes in superstitions - old beliefs which are based on magic and mystery rather than science. Many superstitions are connected to food, as we’ll discover in this programme.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right - like throwing salt over your shoulder to stop bad luck.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Oh come on, Rob! You don’t really believe that, do you?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, lots of people do believe food superstitions, including otherwise rational, scientific people. For example, have you ever blown out the candles on a birthday cake and made a wish? Or thrown rice over the bride and groom at a wedding?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Yes to both of those. Maybe I’m more superstitious than I thought!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, before we find out, it’s time for a quiz question about another famous food festival – Halloween.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: That’s when people carve scary faces into pumpkins to frighten away evil spirits.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes. Right. The tradition of carving pumpkins, or Jack o’ Lanterns as they’re called in the United States, started out as a Celtic festival in Ireland - but it was the Americans who started using pumpkins. So what vegetable did the Irish originally use to scare away ghosts? Was it: a) turnips? b) potatoes?,  or c) squash?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll say b) potatoes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out the right answer later on. What’s for sure is that cultures from around the world have been connecting food and magic for thousands of years, and over time it’s created some strange beliefs.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Here’s food historian Tasha Marks describing one unusual superstition to BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain:

transcript.author: Tasha Marks
transcript.text: When you have superstitions and they sort of mix with science and health and medicine… and one of the examples of that would be something like garlic which… we all know garlic wards off vampires but it’s also been thought to ward off the ‘ evil eye’ , and if you come across the term, the ‘evil eye’, it’s a sort of blanket term that sort of applies to any bad luck.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Tasha says that garlic is believed to ward off vampires, meaning to repel or stop someone from harming you.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: According to this superstition, garlic also keeps away the evil eye – bad luck or magical spells with the power to cause bad things to happen.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Tasha describes the ‘evil eye’ as a blanket term for any bad luck. Just as a real blanket covers the different parts of your body, a blanket term is aphrase that’s used to describe many examples of related things.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: But food superstitions aren’t only about bad luck - they also give our lives meaning.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Jonty Rajagopalan owns a tourist agency in Hyderabad, India, where she introduces visitors to some of the city’s food traditions.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Here she is talking with BBC World Service’s, The Food Chain, about a tradition connected with the Hindu New Year. Can you spot the different tastes she mentions?

transcript.author: Jonty Rajagopalan
transcript.text: Some of the traditions give you a little bit of a lesson , like every new year, and not 1st January, not the Gregorian calendar New Year, but the Hindu calendar New Year, we would always be given… it’s a kind of a chutney which is made of all the five tastes:  so you have sour, you have sweet, you have something bitter in it and your mum would always give it to you saying that this is what the rest of the year is going to be – you’ll have happiness, you’ll have challenges, you’ll have a little sadness, you’ll have bitterness in your life, which I think is a very nice tradition – it prepares you for everything in life.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: At Hindu New Year, mothers give their children a special chutney – a mixture of fruit, spices, sugar and vinegar. Did you spot the chutney’s flavours, Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: There was sour, sweet and bitter.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Mothers tell their children that the coming year, like the chutney, will have its own flavours, both good and bad.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: That’s why Jonty says that traditions can teach (you) a lesson – they show you what you should or shouldn't do in the future, as a result of experience.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: What a lovely way to end our look at food superstitions!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Yes, maybe we should make chutney at Halloween, instead of carving pumpkins – or whatever vegetable the Irish originally used.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ah, yes – in my quiz question I asked you what vegetable was originally used instead of pumpkins to scare away ghosts.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I guessed it was b) potatoes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Which was… the wrong answer! In fact, turnips were originally used, so maybe Irish ghosts are smaller than American ones!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned about superstitions – old beliefs which are connected with magic.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Garlic is supposed to ward off, or keep away, dangers like the evil eye - bad luck or harmful magic.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: The evil eye is an example of a blanket term – a phrase used to describe many examples of related things.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: One Indian superstition involves chutney – a food mixing many flavours

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: These traditions can teach you a lesson - show you how to act in the future based on your past experience.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right. Well, that’s all for this programme. Good luck with your language learning!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And if you’ve enjoyed this topical discussion and want to learn how to use the vocabulary found in headlines, why not try out our News Review podcast? Bye for now!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye bye!
